page.title: JavaScript Array
page.heading: Array
page.intro: An Array is an object used by JavaScript to make lists. These lists can store different data types in an ordered way meaning the position of each list item is numbered/indexed by JavaScript to make them easy to find. They are constructed of square brackets, which contain a list of items separated by commas.

copy3: In this example, each item in the shoppingList array is a string, but you can store any type of item in an array: string, number, object, variable, even another array.

SECTION
copy: Each item in the array has a numbered position. This is it's index. We can access a specific item using it's index. JavaScript counts from 0 and not 1, so the first item in the array will always have the index of 0. This is because JavaScript is zero-indexed.
We want to get milk from our shoppingList array. This item has the index of 1. You can access the individual items in the array using bracket notation.
content.label: CODE/MARKUP
copy2: You can also modify an item in an array by simply giving the item a new value. Let's remove 'milk' from our shoppingList and replace it with 'hot chocolate'.
content.label: CODE/MARKUP
code2: shoppingList[1] = 'hot chocolate';    // Modify the item in the array
